title: How You Show You Care
description: Discover the daily ways you express love and find comfort.

questions.text: What's my favorite love language to receive?

therapeutic.rationale: Gary Chapman's love languages framework identifies primary ways people receive love: words (verbal affirmation), service (helpful actions), time (undivided attention), and touch (physical affection). Most of us have one or two primary receiving languagesâ€”knowing your partner's helps you love them in ways they can actually feel.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different receiving languages is the norm, not the exception. The touch-receiver may not feel loved by words alone; the time-receiver may feel unloved despite many acts of service. Learn to give love in your partner's language, not just your own.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared receiving languages mean you'll naturally feel loved by the same things. Your love naturally translates because you speak the same dialect.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Which love language makes you feel most loved? Is your partner speaking it regularly? What would change if they knew this was your primary language?

questions.text: When I give you gifts, what matters most to me?
choices: That it's something you really wanted
That it shows I was thinking of you

therapeutic.rationale: Gift-giving reveals what we value in exchanges of care. Want-based givers prioritize fulfilling desires; thought-based givers want to demonstrate attention; sentimental givers seek emotional resonance; reaction-based givers need visible appreciation. Understanding what your partner values in giving helps you receive their gifts in ways that satisfy them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different giving values can create disconnection. The sentimental giver may feel hurt if their meaningful gift is casually received; the reaction-seeker needs visible delight. Receive gifts in ways that honor what your partner put into them.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared giving values mean you'll approach presents similarly. You'll understand why each other's gifts matter and how to receive them meaningfully.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you give your partner a gift, what response would make you feel your gift landed? What makes a gift feel successful to you?

questions.text: What's my favorite way you show you care?
choices: Remembering small details about my life
Making me laugh when I'm stressed
Taking care of me when I'm sick
Checking in on me throughout the day

therapeutic.rationale: Daily care has many faces: remembered details show attention; stress-relief humor shows attunement; sick care shows nurturing; check-ins show consistent thinking. These small expressions of care, what Gottman calls 'bids for connection,' accumulate into deep relationship satisfaction over time.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different favorite care expressions mean you're each touched by different daily gestures. The detail-rememberer needs to feel known; the check-in lover needs to feel thought of throughout the day. Do your partner's favorite care gesture often.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared care preferences mean the same daily expressions will connect you both. You'll naturally care for each other in ways that land.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What small thing does your partner do that reliably makes you feel cared for? Do they know this is special to you? When did they last do it?

questions.text: How do I prefer you to comfort me?

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort preferences often reflect attachment patterns and emotional processing styles. Quiet presence soothes without demands; hugs provide physical co-regulation; validation normalizes feelings; solutions address problems. Partners often default to giving comfort how they'd want it, not how their partner needs it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different comfort needs are extremely common and cause much relationship friction. The validation-seeker feels dismissed by solutions; the solution-seeker feels frustrated by 'just listening.' Ask: 'Do you want me to listen or help fix it?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched comfort preferences mean you'll naturally soothe each other in ways that work. When one of you is hurting, the other instinctively knows what to do.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're upset, what does ideal comfort look like? Does your partner know this? What happens when they comfort you differently than you need?

questions.text: What makes me feel most secure in your love?
choices: How you talk about me to others

therapeutic.rationale: Security in love comes from different sources. Consistent affection provides daily reassurance; future planning shows long-term thinking; positive public speech shows pride; crisis commitment proves reliability. Understanding what makes your partner feel secure helps you provide the specific reassurance they need.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different security sources mean different things make you feel safe in the relationship. The consistency-needer needs daily proof; the future-planner needs vision. Prioritize what makes your partner feel secure.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared security sources mean you'll build safety in the same way. You're both reassured by the same things, making security easier to maintain.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel secure in your partner's love? When do doubts creep in? What would help you feel more consistently safe in the relationship?
